Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a CNC Micro-Milling Workstation to Enhance Multidisciplinary Research and Teaching at Texas A&M International University and Texas A&M Kingsville

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Kim, Namwon
Proposal: 1429556
Title: MRI: Acquisition of a CNC Micro-Milling Workstation to Enhance Multidisciplinary Research and Teaching at Texas A&M International University and Texas A&M Kingsville

Significance
The new capabilities of the instrument will create an immediate and lasting impact on their ability to recruit high-quality faculty members. As Villanova hires its next generation of faculty members, it will be offer access to leading-edge equipment. The emphasis on nanomaterials fabrication and development necessitates the upgrading of their experimental facilities to attract leading researchers and educators who can make an immediate impact as they join this dynamic group. The PI and co-PIs are all dedicated to improving opportunities and access for under-represented minorities in engineering and the sciences and two of the principals on this grant are female STEM faculty members. The five PIs combined are advising 16 graduate students, 7 of whom are women, and are working with 19 undergraduate students, including 5 women. Bryn Mawr College was established in 1885 as the first institution in the US to offer Ph.D. degrees to women and the undergraduate program remains all-female, featuring 1300 women, 26% of whom are majoring in math or science. The Villanova College of Engineering also features one of the highest percentages of female students studying engineering, at almost 1/3 of the engineering school enrollment.

Technical Description
The requested workstation will serve as a vehicle to draw undergraduate and graduate students into multidisciplinary science and engineering research at TAMIU and TAMUK, which are two main institutions providing STEM programs to historically underrepresented minority students in South Texas. The workstation will broaden the capability of manufacturing and enhance the quality of the undergraduate research opportunities. Specifically, the new micro-manufacturing equipment will enable students to conduct research in a variety of emerging research areas, including microfabrication, microfluidic devices, and bio-micromechanicalelectrical systems (bio-MEMS), which are relatively new to students in South Texas. The PI and co-PIs are well trained in the new areas from highly research oriented institutions and they are all on the frontier of their research fields and very active in publishing and attending professional conferences to disseminate and share their research findings. They will also continue to make research experiences available any time of the year for motivated students by integrating the use of the workstation into the courses, workshops as well as senior projects and encourage them to publish scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI grant supported the acquisition of a CNC Micro-Milling Workstation for inter-institutional research collaboration between Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK) and Texas A&M International University (TAMIU) on microfabrication, microfluidic devices, and bio-micro-mechanical-electrical systems.

Intellectual merit: The CNC Micro-Milling Workstation was installed and located in the department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering at TAMUK and has been used for several research projects to increase on-going multidisciplinary research activities, broaden the capability of manufacturing and enhance the quality of the undergraduate research opportunities at TAMUK and TAMIU.  The increased capabilities from the CNC Micro-Milling workstation enabled PI, faculty members, and students to manufacture complicated, highly accurate micro-scale parts and components cost-effectively for the projects in heat transfer and/or microfluidic research area.  The installed workstation supported the projects in developing micro-scale micro-channels to improves the analysis methods of flow and heat transfer mechanism and providing feasible design ideas to mimic the nature to improve the flow transport and heat transfer performances. In addition to reducing volume and processing time, the miniaturization of systems improves the heat transport and the molecular diffusion behaviors due to the increased surface to volume ratio and the development of Lab-on-a-chip or Micro Total Analysis Systems emerging as leading contenders. Several micro-channels designs were developed for heat transfer systems and micro-fluidic systems for LAB-on-Chip devices. These micro- channels were manufactured using the CNC micro-milling workstation and the products are about to be tested with currently developing experimental setups.

Broader Impact: The acquisition of the new CNC micro-milling workstation enables to increase the chance of multi-disciplinary activities through senior design projects as well as graduate student research projects by newly introduced micro-scale manufacturing methods and its capability of creating micro-scale product easily and cost effectively. As the installed CNC micro-milling workstation showed the possibility to meet the increasing demand of cost-effective analytical systems which allow biologists and chemists to save their resources and time while retaining reliable outputs from their experiments, this workstation helps to attract undergraduate and graduate students into multidisciplinary science and engineering research at TAMUK and TAMIU with improving the quality of current science and engineering programs by integrating hands-on operations in senior projects and research projects in microfabrication, microfluidic devices, micro-mechanical-electrical systems.  In addition, the workstation created and provides extended incorporating education and research environment between TAMUK and surrounding and other collaborating institutions including Texas A&M University- Corpus Christi (TAMUCC), Texas State University, and University of Texas-Rio Grande Valley (UT-RGV) to develop collaborating research projects using the CNC micro-milling workstation.

Results from the award: During the award period, four journal papers were published, and one is under the review. Through the project, four master’s these and several undergraduate research projects were completed. In addition, more than dozen presentations were made to disseminate the project activities focusing on the advertisement of the acquisition with introducing the capability of the CNC micro-milling workstation and suggesting feasible projects to enhance public understanding and increase interest in learning in science and engineering technology. The project also supported the second-place award in Master’s level poster presentation in a Research Symposium and led wining grants including NIH in 2017.

Modified by: Sangsoo Lee
